cards.title: Huge arching eruption on sun's surface captured by Nasa
cards.rawTitle: Huge arching eruption on sun's surface captured by Nasa

item.title: Huge arching eruption on sun's surface captured by Nasa
item.trailText: Nasa's Solar Dynamics Observatory caught this vision of an arching eruption on the side of the sun over 18 June
item.standFirst: Nasa's Solar Dynamics Observatory caught this vision of an arching eruption on the side of the sun over 18 June. The imagery is shown in the wavelength of extreme ultraviolet light which highlights material in the low parts of the sun's atmosphere and is typically colorised in red. This clip covers about four hours of the event

stillImage.caption: Nasa?s Solar Dynamics Observatory caught this image of an eruption on the side of the sun over June 18, 2015. Uploaded 01 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa Photograph: Nasa
stillImage.cleanCaption: Nasa?s Solar Dynamics Observatory caught this image of an eruption on the side of the sun over June 18, 2015. Uploaded 01 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa

image.altText: arching eruption
image.cleanCaption: Nasa’s Solar Dynamics Observatory caught this image of an eruption on the side of the sun over June 18, 2015. Uploaded 01 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa

item.title: Heatwave beats down on UK
item.trailText: Warmest temperatures in a decade … hottest day ever … phew, what a scorcher … the superlatives are out and so are the crowds as Britain laps up the sunshine
item.standFirst: Warmest temperatures in a decade … hottest day ever … phew, what a scorcher … the superlatives are out and so are the crowds as Britain laps up the sunshine

cards.title: Readers' travel photography competition winners: June – symmetry
cards.rawTitle: Readers' travel photography competition winners: June – symmetry

item.title: Readers' travel photography competition winners: June – symmetry
item.trailText: For this month’s theme of symmetry, readers captured some striking images of everyday life, natural beauty and some of the world’s most iconic buildings
item.standFirst: For this month’s theme of symmetry, readers captured striking images of everyday life, natural beauty and some of the world’s most iconic buildings. Scroll to see the winner, judged by Mick Ryan of fotovue.com. Each monthly winner will have their photograph mounted by Point 101 and displayed in an exhibition at the Guardian’s London office. The best shot of the year wins an Arctic activity and photography trip to Swedish Lapland

displayImages.caption:
Ben Hemmings
On 23 October, Thailand celebrates the King’s birthday. This was the big finale in 2014, not long after the royalist coup. Hundreds of local schoolchildren are executing a choreographed and synchronised meditation towards their head of state. A powerful, visually intriguing and politically poignant moment.
displayImages.altText: Thailand celebrates the King’s Birthday. Hundreds of local school children are executing a choreographed and synchronised meditation towards their head of state.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Ben Hemmings
On 23 October, Thailand celebrates the King’s birthday. This was the big finale in 2014, not long after the royalist coup. Hundreds of local schoolchildren are executing a choreographed and synchronised meditation towards their head of state. A powerful, visually intriguing and politically poignant moment.

displayImages.caption:
Chris Nicholls
A late-night tram in front of Bordeaux Palais de la Bourse, with the lights reflecting back in the miroir d’eau. Inspired by the location’s potential, I waited for the moment a bright pink and blue tram stopped, with the camera set at 10 seconds exposure.
displayImages.altText: A late night tram in front of Bordeaux Palais de la Bourse.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Chris Nicholls
A late-night tram in front of Bordeaux Palais de la Bourse, with the lights reflecting back in the miroir d’eau. Inspired by the location’s potential, I waited for the moment a bright pink and blue tram stopped, with the camera set at 10 seconds exposure.

displayImages.caption:
Claire Brown
The new pier at Swanage in Dorset.
displayImages.altText: The new pier at Swanage in Dorset.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Claire Brown
The new pier at Swanage in Dorset.

displayImages.caption:
mattparry
The symmetrical lines of the Habib Bourguiba Mausoleum in Monastir, Tunisia.
displayImages.altText: The symmetrical lines of the Habib Bourguiba Mausoleum in Monastir, Tunisia
displayImages.cleanCaption:
mattparry
The symmetrical lines of the Habib Bourguiba Mausoleum in Monastir, Tunisia.

displayImages.caption:
Norman Spines
I was just thinking how close the wheel was to the Selfridges store in Manchester when I saw the reflection in the glass and liked the symmetry.
displayImages.altText: Wheel close to the Selfridges store in Manchester.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Norman Spines
I was just thinking how close the wheel was to the Selfridges store in Manchester when I saw the reflection in the glass and liked the symmetry.

displayImages.caption:
Roslin Zuha
Reflections at Glencoe, Scotland. Driving through the expanse, the serenity and splendour of this incredible landscape was stunning. Reflections in Loch Achtriochtan gave the impression of a view through a kaleidoscope.
displayImages.altText: Reflections at Glencoe
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Roslin Zuha
Reflections at Glencoe, Scotland. Driving through the expanse, the serenity and splendour of this incredible landscape was stunning. Reflections in Loch Achtriochtan gave the impression of a view through a kaleidoscope.

displayImages.caption:
Adele Atkinson
The first time I visited Sydney I fell in love with the Opera House. Its architecture is beautiful and its size can only be appreciated when seeing it in person.
displayImages.altText: The first time I visited Sydney I fell in love with the Opera House
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Adele Atkinson
The first time I visited Sydney I fell in love with the Opera House. Its architecture is beautiful and its size can only be appreciated when seeing it in person.

displayImages.caption:
Chloe Beale
Where sea meets sky; Cephalonia, Greece. Long exposure crop.
displayImages.altText: Where sea meets sky, Cephalonia, Greece. Long exposure crop.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Chloe Beale
Where sea meets sky; Cephalonia, Greece. Long exposure crop.

displayImages.caption:
tellig
I was immediately attracted to the eye-catching colours of the spices carefully arranged in receding rows. I waited until the distant legs came into view to enhance the background.
displayImages.altText: I was immediately attracted to the eye-catching colours of the spices carefully arranged in receding rows. I waited until the distant legs came into view to enhance the background.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
tellig
I was immediately attracted to the eye-catching colours of the spices carefully arranged in receding rows. I waited until the distant legs came into view to enhance the background.

displayImages.caption:
Ruth Grindrod, runner-up
Buttermere, in the Lake District, on a perfectly still spring morning.

Mick Ryan, judge
Symmetry is abundant in nature and landscapes, and nothing show this off better than a reflection. We are hardwired to be instantly attracted to symmetry and it’s a bonus if the symmetry is caused by a reflection, as this photograph on a calm day in the Lake District shows.
displayImages.altText: Buttermere, in the Lake District, on a perfectly still spring morning.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Ruth Grindrod, runner-up
Buttermere, in the Lake District, on a perfectly still spring morning.

Mick Ryan, judge
Symmetry is abundant in nature and landscapes, and nothing show this off better than a reflection. We are hardwired to be instantly attracted to symmetry and it’s a bonus if the symmetry is caused by a reflection, as this photograph on a calm day in the Lake District shows.

displayImages.caption:
Katie Mankin, runner-up
A royal guard at Gyeongbokgung Palace, Seoul, South Korea.

Mick Ryan, judge
The symmetry of the subject’s face – peak beard – his costume, the pagoda and the simple colours are beguiling and mysterious. I liked the position of the ‘Dalek’ on top of his hat – or is that the top of the pagoda? This image would have won if the bottom of the beads had been included.
displayImages.altText: A royal guard at Gyeongbokgung Palace, Seoul, South Korea.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Katie Mankin, runner-up
A royal guard at Gyeongbokgung Palace, Seoul, South Korea.

Mick Ryan, judge
The symmetry of the subject’s face – peak beard – his costume, the pagoda and the simple colours are beguiling and mysterious. I liked the position of the ‘Dalek’ on top of his hat – or is that the top of the pagoda? This image would have won if the bottom of the beads had been included.

displayImages.caption:
Matt Davies, winner
Passengers travel in and out of the abyss at Dupont Circle metro station in Washington DC.

Mick Ryan, judge
This photograph is more than just symmetry. Several compositional elements combine to make it a strong image, including converging lines, curves, off-setting, framing, patterns, and figures in an urban landscape emerging and descending. The conversion to black and white simplifies the image and makes these elements even more apparent. A worthy winner.
displayImages.altText: Passengers travel in to and out of the abyss at Dupont Circle metro station in Washington DC.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Matt Davies, winner
Passengers travel in and out of the abyss at Dupont Circle metro station in Washington DC.

Mick Ryan, judge
This photograph is more than just symmetry. Several compositional elements combine to make it a strong image, including converging lines, curves, off-setting, framing, patterns, and figures in an urban landscape emerging and descending. The conversion to black and white simplifies the image and makes these elements even more apparent. A worthy winner.

cards.title: Police hold biggest ever terror training drill in London
cards.rawTitle: Police hold biggest ever terror training drill in London

item.title: Police hold biggest ever terror training drill in London
item.trailText: The Metropolitan police and other emergency services trained in a staged scenario that pitted them against a group of marauding attackers
item.standFirst: The Metropolitan police and other emergency services trained in a staged scenario that pitted them against a group of marauding attackers

displayImages.caption: Police officers in operation Strong Tower, the Met’s biggest ever terrorism drill Photograph: Peter Nicholls /Reuters
displayImages.altText: Police officers in operation Strong Tower, the Met’s biggest ever terrorism drill
displayImages.cleanCaption: Police officers in operation Strong Tower, the Met’s biggest ever terrorism drill

displayImages.caption: Actors hold firearms outside the disused Aldwych underground train station as they test the abilities of emergency services to respond to an extremist attack in London Photograph: Matt Dunham/AP
displayImages.altText: Actors hold firearms outside the disused Aldwych underground train station as they test the abilities of emergency services to respond to an extremist attack in London
displayImages.cleanCaption: Actors hold firearms outside the disused Aldwych underground train station as they test the abilities of emergency services to respond to an extremist attack in London

cards.title: Beauty in ruins / Abandoned places in Europe and Asia
cards.rawTitle: Abandoned places in Europe and Asia

item.title: Beauty in ruins: abandoned places in Europe and Asia
item.trailText: The ghost town of Pripyat, near Chernobyl, and derelict sites around Europe and central Asia became evocative locations for urban explorer David de Rueda on a six-week tour discovering hidden relics of the recent past – as part of Nikon’s Project Spotlight: Abandoned Places
item.standFirst: The ghost town of Pripyat, near Chernobyl, and derelict sites around Europe and central Asia became evocative locations for urban explorer David de Rueda on a six-week tour discovering hidden relics of the recent past – as part of Nikon’s Project Spotlight: Abandoned Places

displayImages.caption:
Lost in space
This image is the result of 180km of off-road driving in the Kazakhstan desert, followed by 45km of walking in a highly-restricted area. We arrived and there they were: two relics of the space race in a huge abandoned warehouse. It may be the single most epic scene I’ve discovered since picking up a camera.
• All photographs: David de Rueda
displayImages.altText: Lost in space. Former space shuttle facility in Kazakhstan
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Lost in space
This image is the result of 180km of off-road driving in the Kazakhstan desert, followed by 45km of walking in a highly-restricted area. We arrived and there they were: two relics of the space race in a huge abandoned warehouse. It may be the single most epic scene I’ve discovered since picking up a camera.
• All photographs: David de Rueda

displayImages.caption:
Night souls
In an otherwise deserted area on Iceland’s south coast is this long-forgotten wreck of a Douglas DC-3 aircraft. I arrived at the location at 4am and, as we waited, polar lights appeared on the horizon. I admired this magic show until dawn and used a 90-second exposure, with some light painting added inside the plane, to capture this image.
displayImages.altText: Douglas DC-3 aircraft wreck in south Iceland
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Night souls
In an otherwise deserted area on Iceland’s south coast is this long-forgotten wreck of a Douglas DC-3 aircraft. I arrived at the location at 4am and, as we waited, polar lights appeared on the horizon. I admired this magic show until dawn and used a 90-second exposure, with some light painting added inside the plane, to capture this image.

displayImages.caption:
The signal
Under the congress room of the Buzludzha monument in Bulgaria I discovered a place that seemed to be from another planet. I used my torch to light it up and discovered everything was covered with ice.
displayImages.altText: Room under the congress room of the Buzludzha monument in Bulgaria
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The signal
Under the congress room of the Buzludzha monument in Bulgaria I discovered a place that seemed to be from another planet. I used my torch to light it up and discovered everything was covered with ice.

displayImages.caption:
Time capsule
In Budapest I explored this derelict train graveyard. It’s in the middle of an active depot and I felt like a child escaping reality to walk for a few hours in an imagined world of steel monsters.
displayImages.altText: Derelict train depot in Budapest
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Time capsule
In Budapest I explored this derelict train graveyard. It’s in the middle of an active depot and I felt like a child escaping reality to walk for a few hours in an imagined world of steel monsters.

displayImages.caption:
High frequency
This picture was taken in a disused experimental power facility near Moscow, which was closely guarded by half a dozen dogs. After a little persuasive discussion, the caretaker let us in. As the sun was setting, I had a few minutes to find the perfect point of view.
displayImages.altText: Disused experimental power facility near Moscow, Russia
displayImages.cleanCaption:
High frequency
This picture was taken in a disused experimental power facility near Moscow, which was closely guarded by half a dozen dogs. After a little persuasive discussion, the caretaker let us in. As the sun was setting, I had a few minutes to find the perfect point of view.

displayImages.caption:
The mothership
Linnahall is a former concert hall in Tallinn, Estonia. With a two-minute exposure, I could reveal the architecture of the place, which otherwise sat in darkness. The central framing gives the photograph its power, drawing the eye right to the centre. To me, it almost looks like a spaceship.
displayImages.altText: Linnahall, a former concert hall in Tallinn, Estonia.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The mothership
Linnahall is a former concert hall in Tallinn, Estonia. With a two-minute exposure, I could reveal the architecture of the place, which otherwise sat in darkness. The central framing gives the photograph its power, drawing the eye right to the centre. To me, it almost looks like a spaceship.

displayImages.caption:
Eternal wait
This is a waiting room in the remains of the hospital in Pripyat, an abandoned city in northern Ukraine, close to the border with Belarus. It was abandoned a couple of days after the Chernobyl disaster. This room caught my eye with its colours and decaying plant life. You get the sense that time has been frozen here.
displayImages.altText: Waiting room in the remains of the hospital in Pripyat, Ukraine
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Eternal wait
This is a waiting room in the remains of the hospital in Pripyat, an abandoned city in northern Ukraine, close to the border with Belarus. It was abandoned a couple of days after the Chernobyl disaster. This room caught my eye with its colours and decaying plant life. You get the sense that time has been frozen here.

displayImages.caption:
Time implosion
A room in the former hospital in Pripyat and one of the first buildings I explored in the city. The oven appears to have exploded in the centre of the room and destroyed everything around it.
displayImages.altText: Former hospital, Pripyat, Ukraine
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Time implosion
A room in the former hospital in Pripyat and one of the first buildings I explored in the city. The oven appears to have exploded in the centre of the room and destroyed everything around it.

displayImages.caption:
Pripyat cafe
This place, again in the city of Pripyat, used to be a cafe. I wanted to highlight the beautiful glasswork and create something unique with a long exposure and light painting. We constructed one main source of light inside the building, a second light behind the Pripyat sign to create a sense of depth and a third illuminating the cafe’s original sign.
displayImages.altText: Former cafe in the ghost city of  Pripyat near Chernobyl
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Pripyat cafe
This place, again in the city of Pripyat, used to be a cafe. I wanted to highlight the beautiful glasswork and create something unique with a long exposure and light painting. We constructed one main source of light inside the building, a second light behind the Pripyat sign to create a sense of depth and a third illuminating the cafe’s original sign.

displayImages.caption:
Child dream
This is from our last day in Pripyat. For the three previous days I asked myself how I could capture the famous ferris wheel from a new and original point of view. Luckily, my wish to have some snow was fulfilled, providing a dreamy ambience that totally changed Pripyat. Positioning myself on a rooftop next to the wheel, I finally captured the picture I was looking for.
displayImages.altText: Ferris Wheel, Pripyat, Ukraine
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Child dream
This is from our last day in Pripyat. For the three previous days I asked myself how I could capture the famous ferris wheel from a new and original point of view. Luckily, my wish to have some snow was fulfilled, providing a dreamy ambience that totally changed Pripyat. Positioning myself on a rooftop next to the wheel, I finally captured the picture I was looking for.

cards.title: The week in TV / Glastonbury, True Detective and The Brink
cards.rawTitle: Glastonbury, True Detective and The Brink

item.title: Glastonbury, True Detective and The Brink: TV review
item.trailText: Telly addict Andrew Collins attempts to tear himself away from the BBC's coverage of Glastonbury 2015
item.standFirst:
This week, Andrew Collins tears himself away from the BBC's coverage of Glastonbury 2015 long enough to catch up with the return to Sky Atlanticof HBO's moody, noirish, anthological True Detective; a brand new, big-name political comedy, also from HBO, called The Brink; and a gripping contagion thriller in Flemish, Cordon, on BBC4

• WARNING: CONTAINS STRONG LANGUAGE

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for  Glastonbury, True Detective, The Brink and more:TV review-video  Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: The Africa the media never shows you
cards.rawTitle: The Africa the media never shows you

item.title: The Africa the media never shows you
item.trailText: The hashtag #TheAfricaTheMediaNeverShowsYou goes viral on Twitter as young Africans rush to share positive pictures of the continent
item.standFirst: The hashtag #TheAfricaTheMediaNeverShowsYou goes viral on Twitter as young Africans rush to share positive pictures of the continent
item.body:
The international media’s representation of Africa all too often seems to focus on disaster or catastrophe. But a fightback is now taking place on Twitter, with images being shared by Africans of #TheAfricaTheMediaNeverShowsYou including photos from the fashion industry to the film industry, from pristine beaches to vast university campuses, and from ancient mosques to ultra-modern hospitals.

The hashtag has attracted over 42,000 tweets and retweets so far - but here’s just a few of our favourites.

Join our community of development professionals and humanitarians. Follow@GuardianGDP on Twitter.

displayImages.altText: Chad

image.altText: Chad
